abstract.p: In this paper, a projective synchronization problem of master-slave chaotic systems is investigated. More specifically, a fuzzy adaptive slave chaotic system subject to both sector nonlinearities and dead-zone in the input channel is proposed using only the measurable output of the master system thanks to a suitable observer. The asymptotical projective synchronization between the master and slave systems is achieved by an adequate fuzzy adaptive variable-structure control system. The underlying parameter adaptation design as well as the asymptotical synchronization and stability analysis are carried out using a Lyapunov based approach. The distinctive feature of the control design is that the uncertainties function and the gain reduction tolerances of the dead-zone are no longer required to be known thanks to the parameter adaptation capability of the control system. The proposed synchronization scheme is extended to two classes of the master-slave chaotic systems with time-delays. By using the Lyapunov-Krasovskii approach, some stability conditions relating to these classes are derived. Simulation results are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed projective synchronization scheme.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Chaotic systems are increasingly used in system engineering because of their attractive features, namely a noise-like wave form, a broadband spectrum, unpredictable behavior and an extreme sensitivity to initial conditions as well as parameter variations (Boulkroune et al., 2006a, 2007; Chen and Dong, 1998). Of particular interest, a remarkable research activity has been devoted to the chaos synchronization since the pioneer contributions (Chen and Dong, 1998; Pecora and Carroll, 1990; Yu and Song, 2001). The rationale behind this particular interest is the potential applications of chaos synchronization in secure communications, chemical reactions, biological systems and information processing (Chen and Dong, 1998). A basic configuration of chaos synchronisation consists of two chaotic systems: a master system (or a drive system) and a designed slave system (or a response system). Note that the master and slave systems can be identical with different initial conditionsor quite different. The master system drives the slave system via the transmitted signal so that the trajectory of the master system synchronizes with that of the slave system. Several types of synchronization have been already used in the available applications, namely the complete synchronization (CS) (Bowonga et al., 2006; Carroll et al., 1996; Sun and Zhang, 2004), the phase synchronization (PS) (Pikovsky et al., 1997; Rosenblum et al., 1996), the lag synchronization (LS) (Cailian et al., 2005), the generalized synchronization (GS) (Morgul and Solak, 1996, 1997) and the generalized projective synchronization (GPS) (Jianping and Changpin, 2005; Li, 2006; Li and Xu, 2004).

From the control theory point of view, the slave system can be designed as a state observer for the master system. All of the state variables of the slave system are reconstructed from transmitted signals from the master system, and then all or partial state trajectories of these systems are driven into synchronization through an appropriate control design. Some observer-based synchronization systems have been proposed in Liao and Huang (1999), Wen and Xu (2004, 2005). A key assumption in these synchronization systems is that there is no constraint on the inputs of the slave chaotic system (Liao and Huang, 1999; Wen and Xu, 2004, 2005). This is by no means the case in the real world life as the physical systems commonly involve input saturations, backlash, dead-zone, quantization, sector nonlinearities and so on. It is worth mentioning that the input nonlinearities may lead to poor performances or even instability of the synchronization control system when they are not taken into account into the design. It is thereby more advisable to consider the effects of these input nonlinearities in one way or another when designing and implementing a synchronization control system.

Two synchronization control systems have been recently proposed for a class of chaotic systems with input nonlinearities in Hung et al. (2006, 2008). The contribution in Hung et al. (2008) consists in designing an adaptive projective synchronization system for Chua’s chaotic systems with dead-zone and sector nonlinearities under three restrictive assumptions. 1) The state vector of the master system is completely available for measurement. 2) The nonlinear function appearing in the dynamics of Chua’s system is bounded by a constant. 3) The gain reduction tolerances of the input nonlinearity are required to be known. The contribution in Hung et al. (2006) consists in designing an observer-based generalized projective synchronization system for a class of chaotic systems with dead-zone under three limitations features. 1) The model of the master system is partially known. 2) The uncertain function in the master model is assumed to be bounded by a nonlinear function depending only on the output of the master system, i.e. the transmitted signal. 3) The model of the input nonlinearity is a simple dead-zone.

Fuzzy systems (FSs) have been successfully applied to many control problems because they do not need an accurate mathematical model of the system under control and they can co-operate with human expert knowledge. It is also known that FSs as well as neural networks (NNs) can approximate uniformly any nonlinear continuous function over a compact set (Wang, 1994). Thanks to the universal approximation theorem (Wang, 1994), adaptive fuzzy control schemes have been developed for nonlinear and chaotic uncertain systems in (Boulkroune et al., 2006b, 2008, 2009; Liu and Wang, 2007; Liu et al., 2010; Tong and Li, 2002; Wang, 1994; Zhang and Bien, 2000; Zhang et al., 2000) and (Hwang et al., 2009; Liu and Zheng, 2009; Poursamad and Markazi, 2009; Roopaei and Zolghadri Jahromi, 2008), respectively. The stability of the underlying closed-loop system has been analyzed using a Lyapunov approach. Compared with conventional adaptive control schemes, the advantage of the adaptive fuzzy control schemes is that there is no need for a linear parameterisation condition. To cope with the approximation error and external disturbances, these adaptive fuzzy controllers are augmented by a robust compensator which can be a sliding mode control and/or a control. In Roopaei and Zolghadri Jahromi (2008) and Hwang et al. (2009), fuzzy-adaptive controllers are designed to perform a suitable synchronization between the master and slave systems. A key assumption in these synchronization control systems is that the slave chaotic systems have been considered with linear inputs.

This paper aims to address the projective synchronization problem of a class of chaotic systems subject to both sector nonlinearity and dead-zone in the input channel using a suitable fuzzy adaptive observer-based approach. The master and slave systems are coupled only by a scalar transmitted signal and only the output of the master system is assumed to be measured. An observer-based slave system and a fuzzy adaptive variable-structure controller are designed to perform a suitable synchronization of the master and slave systems. A Lyapunov approach is adopted to carry out the parameter adaptation design and convergence and stability analysis involved in the proposed synchronisation system. Bearing in mind the available results (Hung et al., 2006, 2008), three engineering features are worth to be mentioned.

list-item.p: The nonlinear part of the master system model is completely unknown. An upper bound of the underlying function is estimated using the fuzzy adaptive system.

The considered class of chaotic systems is rather larger in the sense that the unknown nonlinear function could depend on the full state vector. This is not the case in Hung et al. (2006) where such a function is assumed to be bounded and this bound depends only on the output of the master system. This assumption is fully exploited in the controller design as well as the stability analysis.
The knowledge of the gain reduction tolerances of the nonlinear dead-zones is no longer required when implementing the controller.

In section 4, this projective synchronization problem is extended to two classes of the master-slave chaotic systems with time-delays. The stability conditions associated are derived via Lyapunov-Krasovskii approach.

sec.title: 2. Problem formulation
sec.p:
As mentioned in the introduction, the main motivation of this paper consists in investigating a projective synchronization problem of master-slave chaotic systems subject to both sector nonlinearities and dead-zone in the input channel. The transmitted signal is the measurable output of the master system. And the projective synchronization between the master and slave systems is achieved by an adequate fuzzy adaptive variable-structure control system as shown in Figure 1. Of particular interest, the synchronisation is performed throughout a proportional relation between the synchronized systems defined by scaling factor λ. Figure 1.
The proposed synchronization system.

More specifically, we will consider the following class of chaotic systems as the master system: (1) with (2) where x∈Rn and y∈R denote respectively the state vector and the output of the system and A is a known system matrix with an appropriate dimension. The underlying modeling assumptions are
Assumption 1. (A, B) is controllable and (CT, A) is observable.
Assumption 2. There is a constant vector L∈Rn such that the transfer function H(s)=CT[sI−(A−LCT)]−1B is strictly positive real (SPR).
Assumption 3. The state variables are not available for measurement, except the system output.
Assumption 4. The analytical function f(x) is unknown.
The following remarks allow to motivate the above assumptions with respect to the considered design framework:
Remark 1. Assumption 1 is an usual assumption in system theory.
Remark 2. Although Assumption 2 is too restrictive, it is satisfied by commonly used chaotic systems, namely the Chua’s systems and the Van der Pol-Duffing oscillators.

According to the well known Kalman and Yakubovich Lemma (Ionnou and Sun, 1996), the SPR condition of H(s) guarantees that for a given matrix Q1=Q1T>0, there exists a matrix P1=P1T>0 such that the following matrix equations (3) hold.
Remark 3. Assumption 3 is indeed coherent with respect to the secure communication practice as the transmitted signal consists in the master system output.

Remark 4. Assumption 4 shows that the prior knowledge on the master system is reduced with respect to the recent contributions, e.g. the function f(x) has been assumed to be partially known and depends only on the output in Hung et al. (2006).

sec.p:

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: A fuzzy adaptive observer-based approach has been presented in this paper to deal with the projective synchronization problem of a class of chaotic systems involving both sector nonlinearity and dead-zone in the control channel. The slave system consists of a suitable observer of the master system, thereby making it possible to deal with the measurement requirements of the master system state variables. The underlying master and slave systems are coupled only by a scalar transmitted signal, namely the measured output of the master system. The synchronization is achieved by a fuzzy adaptive variable structure controller. Of fundamental interest, a suitable Lyapunov based analysis has been carried out to conclude the stability as well as the synchronization error convergence of the proposed observer-based projective synchronization system. In section 4, we attempted to extend our fundamental results to two classes of the master-slave chaotic systems with time-delays. By using the Lyapunov-Krasovskii approach, some stability conditions relating to these classes have been obtained. Simulation results have been given to emphasize the effectiveness of the proposed synchronization system.
